reviewText:
Tokyo Drift? Initial D? VDrift? If anything of this appeals to you, this might too.

In any case, this game's remarkable. It's challenging, exciting and unforgiving. But let me tell you, it's just as satisfying once you get a feel for it.

You start out in a minimalistic world, sitting in the infamous Toyota Trueno AE86. Your destiny? Drift. A brief tutorial follows, which will probably result in you crashing into walls a lot, but that's fine, as nothing else really is needed to understand how this game works! The game then releases you into a free-roaming environment with a few missions you have to do to unlock more stages. You can then also select stages, cars and tracks once in Free-roam mode, a bit like in NFS or other racing titles.

As you get more familiar with the controls, the stages get more exciting and challenging/longer. They also come in several formats: Lap-based drift-tracks, Driftkhana, which is a highscore time-attack inside an arena, or mountain sprint tracks. The goal is always the same, drift gracefully, score points, interact with objects such as poles to drift past or boxes to shatter, add that up to the final score and remain away from hitting walls or losing your combo. Sounds easier than it is, trust me, the Japanese themed tracks and names will kick into your curb at first.

That said, car handling is the key, each car has their own way of handling, so finding what suits you most will be the way to go. Ontop of that, drifting's the deal, so going fast won't always be the key to success either. Manual or automatic shifting? How high should be the turning sensitivity? Well, all these factors will help you optimize your driving style, making it possible to reach up to be the drift king.

I personally had, and will have a blast with this title in the future. It's been a while since I found an appealing drifting/racing experience and I can safely say this game has done it right. Now go... Go... and be the next Drift-King.

reviewText:
Absolute Drift is a *gasp* drifting game. Of course the most important part of a vehicle game of any sort are the controls. I will admit that the controls in Absolute Drift are quite tight while the driving itself does feel a bit too slippery, but as you might guess it’s not a big deal in a game where your only goal is to slide stylishly. Absolute Drift also boasts a unique Japanified minimalist aesthetic, paying homage to one of the origins of the drifting motorsport. It isn’t all roses but let’s not hesitate to pop the hood and see what we got, this is Absolute Drift.

Free Roam mode serves as the Story Mode, and will serve to introduce you to the controls as well as different challenges and events. After spinning out a few times and learning the art of counter-steering you will begin to grasp what the game is really all about and because there is very little hand-holding, conquering a world challenge or topping the global highscore for any track feels like a great accomplishment. Absolute Drift has a total of 23 tracks to enjoy; 10 circuit Drift tracks, 9 open-world Driftkhana courses, and 4 one-way Mountain Drift tracks, so you can find the event that suits you best.

While the world challenges and events have as much variety as can be expected, I find that it still isn’t quite enough. Drift around this, drift between that, it isn’t until the last stage that things start getting really interesting. All I’m saying is I wanted to jump on a few more roofs. Car customization is limited to 6 body-types, which all have a slightly different feel. You can also pick a color and a decal, but nothing beyond that. I would really like a chance to fine-tune my engine and shocks. Stripped-down customization and lack of real-time damage are gigantic missed opportunities.

I enjoyed my time with Absolute Drift, with its low-key dance music soundtrack, inoffensive looks, and high degree of mastery. Lack of customization and content hurts replayability, but the difficulty curve and global scoreboards means it still has quite a bit to offer. The story mode can be completed in around 2 hours, and if that’s all you’re buying this game for then $12 might be a bit overpriced. It is a bit of a one-trick pony, but it does that trick extremely well. If you’re in the mood for a score-attack drifting game, give Absolute Drift a try. Though it might be worth waiting for a sale. Big thanks to Funselektor Labs for the review copy! We at IGB hope to see more quite soon.

reviewText:
This is an excellent, laid back game about drifting through life with a chill soundtrack in the background and some really interesting physics-based gameplay in the foreground.

Keep in mind that mastering control of your car through a drift is the primary gameplay loop here, so if you simply can't stand ice levels this is probably not the game for you.

If you can get past that, though, there's a beautiful open-ish world (segmented off by challenges) with a wealth of things to drift around, through, in and over - as well as special levels that challenge you to drift through a course, or score as high as possible in an arena with a time limit. There's even a lighthouse named Donut!

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=493072488

At this point, the game's even taken its special anti-nausea edibles - so if you were put off by the camera in older Let's Plays (particularly during spins), give it another shot.

One thing I would like to see is a bit more interactivity throughout the open world - sure, there's challenges you can accomplish and ramps you can jump off of and stacks of blocks you can knock down, but there's not much you can do to change the layout of the levels; it would be neat if you could (for instance) trigger a crane to raise a wall by doing a donut around a lever, or create a ramp by knocking over some of its supports. That sort of thing would be really cool, but it would just be an enhancement on an already great game.

reviewText:
Inspired by Ken Block’s Gymkhana series the best way to describe the game is the driving view point of micro machines, the score system of the trick sections in Project Gotham racing, the progression system of an N64 era platform game and a fantastic drift system that takes an age to master but always makes you feel it is your fault if you screw up.

The game sees you progress through a number of worlds that act as the hub to complete missions. These range from performing stunts around obstacles to performing on tracks to gain points and get a world ranking.

There are 3 types of events Driftkhana, Drifting, & Mountain Drifting but all are essentially a playground to gain as many points as possible. Controlled best with a gamepad the game takes about 5 minutes to understand, 10 minutes to become competent and even after several hours of game play I still did not feel I had truly mastered it.

Visually the game is minimalistic but lovely to look at and run at a solid 60fps. The music soundtrack is also filled with tranquil base numbers.

Now the game is not perfect. Relatively short I finished everything in a few hours and while trying to get higher up the league tables offers the game some replayability I feel that this will not be for everyone. I also felt that a more detailed tutorial to give tips on how to perfect drifting at the start as it took a lot of crashing into walls to really get the difference between how brake and handbrake acts.

I enjoyed the game a lot and for the low price of £9.99 of your regional equivalent it is hard to not recommend but this isn’t a game which you will be playing for ages unless you really are a score attack gamer.

reviewText:
Absolute Drift is an interesting top down car game, that focuses much more on drifting and the control of the car, rather than racing. You'll be doing your best to drift around corners, doing donuts, and fish tails in order to score as much points and to accomplish as much tasks as possible.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IxeLgOZQWTw
Once in the game you'll be thrown into a somewhat open world where you'll be doing various tasks, such as ramp jumping, donuts, fish tails, and other drifting and driving challenges. Once the section of the map's tasks are complete, it'll open up new areas of the game. While exploring this semi-open world, you'll also be given the opportunity to enter one of it's many mini-missions where you'll be aiming for high scores on the leader board. The game also features multiple car models, and colour and pattern customization as well.

The biggest hurdle to Absolute Drift is it's learning curve. It's not an easy game to master and make little concession to beginning or even intermediate players. The controls are difficult at first, as the car feel very differnt from other driving games, and the ground feels something like ice. Spinning out and losing control of your car will probably be your first 30 minutes or more of your experiance. This might prove frustrating to players who don't play a lot of driving games (like me) but when you start to get the hang of things, and the small amounts of progress that you make in your driving ability really does feel rewarding. How ever, if you are a fan of driving games, it's focus on high teir play may very well be an attraction to you.

The game also looks great, as it's polished and clean look catches the eye, with it's minimalist design, with great music that suit the game's look and feel. Infact, the game's OST was one of the main motavators to push through the initial frustration of the controls. I just wanted to keep playing so I could keep listening to the amazing sound track.

Overall, Absolute Drift is an interesting car game that I mostly enjoyed. I loved the presentation, I love the music, I love the concept. The only thing holding me back from enjoying the game to it's full potential is my sucky driving in combination with the game's extremly high learning curve.

Pros
- Great visuals
- Amazing sound track
- An interesting concept
- High teir driving fans would probably love the challenge level

Cons
- Extremely high learning curve
- Frustrating at times

Drifting is the name of the game here and that's precisely what you're gonna get.

Drift around that pole! Sweet!
Now jump over that lake! Awesome!
Get them donuts going on that helipad! Cool!

That's basically it. There's a free-roam mode which consists of several zones with mini-objectives as well as separate events scattered around. Get to the zone, complete objectives, unlock the next one - repeat until you're the drift master.
Events are instances in which you can rack up your personal score and compete with other players via the leaderboards. You have 3 lap drift courses of varying difficulty, driftkhanas, which essentially are closed off arenas in which you race against time to get the highest score possible and you have drift tracks in which you go from point A to point B and get as many points as you can along the way.
The game is short, if you're aiming to 'complete' it. If you're here for the pleasure of drifting though, you can spend hours upon hours perfecting your skills.

The presentation is fantastic with very slick, clean and, most importantly, clear visuals. Music is very catchy and complements the picture in the best possible way.

All in all - if you like stylish visuals, racing and drifting, treat yourself with this little gem.

My 9th most played game on steam and one of the most entertaining games I've played in a long time.

Pros
+++ Steep learning curve. Modern games tend to be way too simplified in terms of mechanical skill required to play in order to appeal much casual audience as possible. Absolute drift is fairly hard to learn, harder to master while keeping it fun doing that.

+ Leaderboards. The main reason of my game time.

+ Minimalistic Graphics. Result is a game that is not power hungry and looks nice and clean.

+ Initial D references and AE86. Love it.

Cons
-If you are looking for story, better go looking at other direction. There isn't one aside being told to become Drifting master" at the beginning.

-Short campaign mode of 30-120 minutes depending how you play it.

-Even though having minimalistic graphics i'd really like seeing some scenery around the maps.

-Performance issues in couple of maps.

-For casual play the price point might not be justified for the reasons addressed above.

reviewText:
Absolute Drift has that borderline feeling between trying to be arcade and trying to be sim, and doing neither well. The camera angle says arcade, the fine control of steering says sim, the overall physics say they don't know what they are - and I don't know either.

With the minimalist single-angle isometric style, they should have gone towards a challenging arcade experience, instead I got a frustrating blend of sim/arcade controls that is derived from what feels like a lightly modified UnityCar 2.0 asset package, which uses Pacejka curves and isn't great for drifting without code voodoo.

The game still has potential to be fun, perhaps alternate camera angles providing a better perspective of what is going on would bring out the game's arcade/sim mixture better and make the controls more enjoyable. As it stands, it's a decent DnB playlist with a car game on top.

Game is fun as I expected... except for one thing: the performance.

It's totally unoptimized for Intel integrated GPUs (HD 3000 in my case). Not sure if it's a game issue or the problem is the Unity engine. I tried the Beta update 3, which uses a newer Unity and... it's even worse. Now even the first world doesn't get to 60fps.

I'll get a refund but still look foward to this game.

This is a really cool game for racing fans, especially those that either, A: feel let down with the lack of drift events in newer games such as GRID Autosport, or B: just like going for high scores on leaderboards. Great presentation and audio mean that it's a pleasure to sit there for an hour or two, plugging away at the High Score on the Driftkhana boards. Take it from me, at the time of the review, I'm ranked anywhere from 2nd to 6th on all of them.

The cars handle nicely, and feel like they have a lot of weight to them. The drifting requires you to think ahead about where you want to end up, and requires minute adjustments as you fly around a corner in order to not crash. It requires a little bit of practice, and top down view can occasionally be disorienting, but overall the game controls well and it feels good. It feels good to slide around a corner at high speed, and consistently nail drifts in order to build up a multiplier and score high points. The games core mechanics are incredibly solid.

The Mirror's Edge style visuals are also a nice touch, and give a lot of flair and personality to the game. The music makes for good background noise, and there are a couple of pretty good tracks that I actually find myself enjoying a lot.

Really, my only complaint is the lack of custom maps. This sort of leaderboard-focused game seems designed to come with a map editor.

Absolute Drift... Let's see; its like Micro Machines meets Mirrors Edge with a soundtrack that takes me back to the early Test Drive and NFS days. Dead simple to pick up and play, but incredibly challenging to master..

The areas in free-roam are large and diverse, flowing seamlessly from industrial districts to twisty mountain passes, which keeps things interesting throughout the map. Visually the game is crisp and clean, dare I say almost elegant in it's minimalistic nature. Because 95% of it is white, it is tricky to see where the track is going uphill or downhill, but even that becomes a moot point once you get used to it.

The way each vehicle slides is surprisingly realistic, with all the usual drift ideas working as you could expect in first-person driving simulators; slamming anchors in the middle of a slide will allow the car to drift out wider, flooring the accelerator with a high angle drift will spin you out more often than not, even the steering feels like the vehicle weight actually transfers fore and aft, allowing for some pretty spectacular moves while flicking the car around tight bends...

Overall, I would recommend this game - it's not perfect, but it's a nice, refreshing take on those old-school, isometric-view racing games. As the name suggests, the focus is on drifting, not lap times. The controls are good with the Xbox 360 gamepad and getting used to the drifting mechanics are what's most difficult. From there, it's drifting accurately that becomes the game since many courses are tight and don't allow much room for error.

The soundtrack is great, the visuals are unique and refreshing, and it's easily one of those games where you can play a couple of quick sessions or play for hours trying to top your high score. There's no multiplayer, but there is a good leaderboard and after each session you'll know what you scored and how you rank worldwide.

My only problem is limited customization of the cars - you can change between a few basic paint colours and patterns, and there are only six cars. Each car has its own unique characteristics and chances are you'll only end up using a couple for the majority of your runs. Given the leaderboard system, I don't expect performance modifications, but greater visual customization would be nice, although it's far from being a gamebreaker.

The core game itself (the free-roam mode) can be finished very quickly (like, an hour), it's the pursuit of accuracy and precision that keeps you coming back. It's a casual game, but you need to play it more than casually if you want to link up sweet drifts through a complete tour of a track.

One of the best drifting games out there. I think it's underrated. One should really consider it on a sale.

Graphics: Interesting simplistic concept.
Vehicle control: Sim-like controls but yet, somewhat arcady. Not very easy to control the car. Which is a good thing for this kind of game.
Music: Not my kind of music. Weird techno-pop-trance ♥♥♥♥ going on.
Cars: Several vehicles to choose from. They differ in speed and handling. You can paint cars and/or put stickers on them!
Level design: Absolutely perfect. In the main story (kind of) area, there are buildings, roads and objects scattered around for your pleasure. A lot of different objects to drift around, through, under and between. Then there are also drift tracks.
There are 3 kinds of drift tracks:
*Mountain drift: No laps, you just go downwards while drifting as much as you can.
*Driftkhana: No laps. A closed off area where you perform drift moves (donuts, jumps, slaloms, drifts) until the timer runs out.
*Drift curcuit: Run 3 laps around while performing drift moves.
Drifting: Collect points for each drift move. More angle and more speed mean more points. You can chain drifts. Careful for if you lose control, you crash. When you crash, you bank your current points but lose your streak.
Single player: There 6 areas, each requiring you to complete a number of tasks before unlocking the gate to the next area. Tasks vary between collecting things, completing certain drift moves, jumping over obstacles and some other stuff.
Multiplayer: There are online leaderboards for all tracks. Try to go higher on each track and see how you fare compared to the general Steam population.
